lines.text: Mama, why am I always a cow in your proverbs?
Are you brave?
What? Well, sometimes.
Are you honest?
Brutally.
But are you romantic?
To a fault. Have you had breakfast?
You can't have breakfast at 4 o'clock.
I can do what I like.
Saracen, will you marry my mother?
[Matthew chuckles]
Will you be my good deed?
I'm much to busy to do that.
You don't have to do anything. I'll come and do things for you.
What on Earth could you possibly do for me?
[he and Sammy just look at each other]
I'll think about it, the next time you come.
Are you going to change?
Into what?
Your Saracen costume.
It itches.
What are you going to say to her?
Good afternoon, Mama Sammy.
Can't you think of anything more exciting than that?

[running into the church with Matthew]
Mama! Mama! Look what I got for you!
Let's walk on. People are staring.
Well, what do you expect? Satan walking you home from church.

[Sammy looks at a cute girl]
Forget it. Bad sign, clog sandals. They're always followed by a father with a shotgun.
[an angry looking man walks past]
See?
How would you like it if I arranged to get her out?
She won't come.
I can put temptation in her way. What does she like?
You have to keep your room tidy.
As bad as that?
How do you write a Saracen story?
I start at the beginning and I know how I want it to end.
My teacher says...
Don't listen to him. He's a loser.
What are you doing?
We're having a shootout.
I don't approve of shooting or guns.
All right. We're playing men who go bang very loudly at one another. Is that all right with you?

[watching Nene and Mama Fola argue in proverbs]
Why are they talking like that?
Proverbs, to be polite.
It doesn't look very polite.
Matthew, what do you know about sex?
Well, uh, men and women are built... differently.
I know all that penis, vagina, rabbit business. I saw a video at Jean Claude's
Rabbit?

[referring to a discussion with his friend about sex]
He says everyone does it.
Yep.
Everyone?
Uh-huh.
Even people I know?
Yes.
Even people who get married?
Especially people who get married.
[Sammy makes a face]
Tough one, I know.
What are you doing in here?
Snooping.
I've read your books. Saracen always "banging" and "screwing" and "nailing." That's not sex. That's carpentry.
The lessons you don't teach him, life will teach him. And life's lessons are bitter.
We're all right Sammy and I. But I'll beat him later if it will make you happy.
Why are you not married?
If it matters so much to you, you find me a husband.
What kind of husband? Foolish antelope?
Honest enough to take on Sammy and me. And brave enough to know the truth. And if he's romantic as well, I'll marry him tomorrow.
Don't you wonder what it would be like to live in the twenty-fifth century?
Sweet Potato, I wonder what it would be like to live in the twentieth century.
You remember "Come end my eternal loneliness. Let us surf Orion on my cosmic chariot."
Definitely one of my earlier efforts.
Hello, Sam.
Are you mad at me too?
No. Why? Should I be?
